bibl.title: Notes from Liberian Legation In U.S. to Department of State, 1862-1898 T807

body.div1:
Now: James G. Blaine Secretary of State Washington **not made out).6 U.S.A
Sir,
I have the honor by direction to inform you that in the month of July 1890, the President *crailing himself of a visit of the Honorable U.W.G all Paris, Attorney General of the Republic, to the United States, thought fit to commission the said office as a general Commissioner Government of the United States on behalf of Liberia, with respect to an impending revolution of her territorial integrity by certain of the European Powers now engaged in a scramble for the remaining portions of the African Continent not yet appropriated by them. Mr. Davis returned to Liberia in the month of Janurary last, and
his
his repost** to the President was to the effect that he had been honored with an interview with the Honorable The Secretary of State at Washington on the 12th November last but that an account of a previous engagment on the part of the Secretary the interview necessarily terminated in a few moments, to be renewed the next day. That in pursuance of this arrangment he had repeatedly called at the Department of State, but that the Secretary times being important nature between the United States and the South American Republics, it was impossible to attain further audience of the Secretary, within the time allothed for this stay in the United States.
Mr Davis further reported that before bearing the United States, he had addressed you from Philadelphia, a despatched under date of 20th November 1890, in which the object sought to be attained by a personal interview was fully set forth, a **cofoy of which I have
the
the honor to enclose, but so far no reply has been recieved to the *samer
I am therefore directed to intomate** to your Mr. Secretary, that within thr last few months, it has come to the knowledge of the Liberian Government, that an arrangment has been entered into between the Governments of Great Britain and France for the delimination of their respective colonies to the North and South of Liberia, which agreement if *canied out in its integrity would have the effect to reduce the Republic to a mer strip along the coast of the Atlantic Ocean, extending coastwise from the Monnah River on the Northwest to Cape Palmas on the Southeast, with an average *beadit of not more than 40 mile from the Coast. An inspection of a series of Maps published by the Royal Geographical Society of Belgium, shows the proposed French possession on the West.
Coast
Coast of Africa immediately South of Liberia to extend from the British Fold Coast ti Cape Palmas, and files the furthest interior limits of Liberia at Boporo, assigning thr intervening country between Boporo and the Niger as either French Territory, am as liable to become a protectorate of France.
The Government of Liberia an becoming cognizant* of this proposed arrangment recently addressed a memorundum to the British Government, protecting against the conclusion of the said Agreement so far as the deprivation of its territory by France is concerned and soliciting the guard offices of said Government on its behalf By command I herewith enclose a similar document soliciting the good offices of the Governments of the United States to *aveath the appropriation of Liberia territory by France, said appropriattion being contrary ti the *netherland had recently set up by the European Powers to regulate their section in making fresh organizations of territory on the African Continent.
I have the honor to be. Sir Your obident Servant E.D. Barday.
